newsitem.title: MEXICO: Stocks rebound to 4th straight record.
newsitem.headline: Stocks rebound to 4th straight record.

text.p: Mexican stocks recovered from an early bout of profit-taking to chalk up their fourth straight record Thursday after bargain-hunters stepped into the market in late trading.
"Such selling as there was withered away. Once profit-taking had taken prices down, buyers came back from the sidelines," one analyst said.

The leading IPC share index rose 20.37 points to 3,578.34. Volume was moderate at 84.1 million shares. Despite the record close, the broad market was mixed. Of a total of 102 stocks traded, losers outnumbered gainers by 44 to 41.
Some dealers said demand for stocks was fuelled by foreign investors taking positions ahead of the weekend and brokers picking up some stocks at bargain prices.
"After many blue chips had soared to resistance, investors turned to less marketable and bargain stocks, such as Camesa," a floor trader said.
Industrial group Camesa ended up 15 centavos ($0.02) at 3.61 pesos ($0.46).
Other dealers noted that sharp gains on Wall Street -- 1.16 percent to a record 6,625.67 on the Dow Jones industrial average -- also bolstered stocks in Mexico.
Analysts felt Mexico's market still had upside potential.
"The market has woken up with a vengeance, and is still sending buying signals," the technical analyst said. "Any corrections will only be to consolidate the upward trend towards 3,600 points."
Debt-stricken holding company Sidek headed the gainers, up ten centavos ($0.01) to 90 centavos ($11.48), but after a minimal last-minute cross trade, dealers said.
Financial group Serfin followed Sidek, up 33 centavos ($0.04) to 3.13 pesos ($0.40), after what analysts said was a technical breakthrough at 2.90 pesos ($0.37).
Another gainer, steelmaker Ahmsa gained 88 centavos ($0.11) to 16.50 pesos ($2.10) in the wake of a long-term buy reccommendation from the Merrill Lynch brokerage, traders said.

Bus and truck manufacturer, Dina, followed Iasasa, after falling 25 centavos ($0.03) to 4.20 pesos ($0.54) after what traders said was a volatile session for its foreign shares on Wall Street, which ended off 1/8 at 2-1/4.
